body:
Hi @retuxx,

For now, it isn't possible but that could be interesting to integrate this kind of feature in Spoon. PR welcome or I'll work on it soon.

I think in order to add this feature the [Processor](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/processing/Processor.java) interface needs to be extended because the method [process](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/processing/Processor.java#L69) does not know whether it is called pre or post order. Do you have any suggestions what to do? I could try to add this feature and making a pr if you are busy at the moment.

I think that the better way is to add a new state in [TraversalStrategy](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/processing/TraversalStrategy.java#L24) and update the logical in [ProcessingVisitor](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/visitor/ProcessingVisitor.java#L81-L94). That seems pretty easy. :)

Yes, but how should I know whether [process](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/processing/Processor.java#L69) (which gets called by [scan](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/visitor/ProcessingVisitor.java#L81-L94)) is called in pre- or in post-order step?

Ok, I see your issue.

In the [Processor](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/processing/Processor.java#L30) interface, you can add 2 methods named `preProcess(CtElement)` and `postProcess(CtElement)` with an empty default implementation in `AbstractProcessor`.

In the [scan](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/visitor/ProcessingVisitor.java#L77) method of `ProcessorVisitor`, you call `preProcess` and `postProcess` after each `process` invocation (to be retro-compatible).

I think that is a good point to start with. Now, how do I apply this idea to the [CtVisitor](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/reflect/visitor/CtVisitor.java)? I could add a pre and post version of each visit function to the interface.

> Now, how do I apply this idea to the CtVisitor?

Why do you want apply this to the `CtVisitor`? `ProcessingVisitor` is the only one which is used to apply a processor.

Maybe I misunderstand the usage of Processors and Visitors. Actually, I would like  calculate some metrics for classes/functions and so on. The general idea is to use a visitor in order to get access to the structure of a class/function. In my scenario I would like to initialize a value before _accepting_ (in the context of the visitor patter) a node and read this value afterwards. The value itself will be modified by other visit methods handling the children nodes.

Extending the `ProcessingVisitor` by applying your suggested patches does not give me the ability to visit a node before and after its accepting, right?

> On 15 Mar 2016, at 14:32, Marcel notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> Maybe I misunderstand the usage of Processors and Visitors. Actually, I would like calculate some metrics for classes/functions and so on. The general idea is to use a visitor in order to get access to the structure of a class/function. In my scenario I would like to initialize a value before accepting (in the context of the visitor patter) a node and read this value afterwards. This value will be modified by other visit methods handling the children nodes.

I believe this is the same case I had with a) calculating a cost-model for each node, and then b) performing modifications based on the cost-model analysis. This lead me to write two different processors and pass the results of the first processor to the second.

â€” Alcides Fonseca

> This lead me to write two different processors and pass the results of the first processor to the second.

I really would like to avoid the usage of two processors as it makes things more complex than it should (You have to add some sort of 'book keeping' code)
A simple solution might be the addition of a 'state' attribute to either `Processor` or `CtVisitor` or both indicating that the process/visit method has been called in pre- or post-order step.

> Extending the ProcessingVisitor by applying your suggested patches does not give me the ability to visit a node before and after its accepting, right?

Yes. With my solution: 
- `preProcess` is called before its acceptings.
- [`super.scan(e)`](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/support/visitor/ProcessingVisitor.java#L88) calls the [`accept` method of the current node](https://github.com/INRIA/spoon/blob/master/src/main/java/spoon/reflect/visitor/CtScanner.java#L145).
- `postProcess` is called at the end of the node processing.

It isn't what you want?

> super.scan(e) calls the accept method of the current node.

Thats right, determining the state (pre or post) from within the Processor should work but how do I get the state from within the actual visitor? The visit methods get called by both the, pre order and the post order step (similar to the process method of the Processor class).

issue.title: Pre post order

repository.name: spoon
repository.description: Spoon is a metaprogramming library to analyze and transform Java source code. :spoon: is made with :heart:, :beers: and :sparkles:. It parses source files to build a well-designed AST with powerful analysis and transformation API.

issue.body: This pr is just a suggestion to handle the feature requested of #557. The general idea is to extend the Processor and CtVisitor class in order to provide a state that can be used to determine if the process/visit method has been called from pre- or from post-order step. The state attribute ensures backward compatibility as the usage of it is optional. Unfortunately, I had to create some code duplications (the setter of the state). Maybe you should enhance the class hierarchy in order to prevent such duplications. Nonetheless, this should not (and actually is not) part of this pr. I'm unsure if calling process twice leads to errors. If yes, we could just remove it as the visit methods are the one I want to get executed twice, before and after. However, running the tests results to an error in spoon.test.intercession.IntercessionTest.testSettersAreAllGood line 202. Maybe you know whats going on here. All other tests pass.

body:
Thank you @GerardPaligot. That is exactly what I was looking for. I thought the recursive descent is handled by the Processor only. Thus, I did not consider to wrap my code around `super.visitCtMethod` (or any visit method).

I've added an example in pr #560. Maybe it helps others requesting this feature. Feel free to merge to to discard :)
